author: gpuhoarder
content: The concept of processing time is interesting to me. If the risk of being uncled grows, I would think the pool nodes would just invest in or develop  “faster/better” hardware. Can anyone point me to any kind of benchmarks or performance analysis on processing time? Shouldn’t this also imply a higher gas limit over time as hardware improves?

author: sky.cactus
content: We only very recently got to a point where blocks are *always* full, so we only recently hit "capacity".  For most of Ethereum's history the gas limit was basically just burst capacity limits.

author: chris2_2_2
content: https://ethstats.net/   some of the pools nodes aren't the best. This site tries to provide stats but also its location based so a node in germany is going to do worse than one in cali. One way to analyze is to look at uncle rates and block fill failures. But thats not everything as larger pools will leave less uncles especially if they've united with nearby pools to uncle others.

author: definitelynotcharles7176
content:
Can anyone explain in theory or provide paper, post, etc, why there is ***any*** non-trivial processing time for transactions?

I know this is a real thing because I've discussed this with pool operators and pay money.

My initial vibe is that it is sort of like high-frequency trading (with people paying millions to have a room near an exchange), a sort of degenerate zero-sum game of pools being first that have no social benefits.

If you have the list of transactions already (and why would you wait for more), packing a block seems like it takes microseconds on an iphone. 

Propagation, network time and topology is the issue, hence my HFT critique above.

author: .vbuterin
content: Because you have to actually execute the transactions

content: What matters for the equilibrium tip is the *marginal* uncle risk

content: As far as I am aware there's no signs that that number is increasing

author: .vbuterin

author: .vbuterin
content: ie. if uncle risk is linear (which as far as I know it seems to be, at least at current margins), then the equilibrium tip is the same regardless of what current usage levels are

author: timbeiko
content: Yeah I guess a simpler version of this attack is: miners are unhappy with a change, so they just raise the block limit as much as they can, regardless of long term effects, to make as much money as possible in a short timeframe.

author: elayne_malachite
content: In defense of miners, increasing the gas limit wouldn't be driven by malice. It just becomes the optimal strategy with 1559's incentives. I'll try to get a better write-up done, like I said in 1559-mining, but I hope that the fact that this wouldn't be driven purely by a desire to hurt the network influences the tone of discussion surrounding it.

author: .vbuterin
content: yeah I don't think there's malice involved, I think there's very real tradeoffs between ability to read the chain and ability to write the chain

author: .vbuterin
content: And there definitely are people who view security as a "sacred value" and reducing fees as "merely improving UX", and don't realize that at current trends people are going to lose more money from fees than they do from security issues, and I'm happy to admit that this is a psychological bias

author: .vbuterin
content: Though on the other side, it is important to not underestimate tail risk

author: .vbuterin
content: A DoS followed by a 1 hour 51% attack could lead to _lots_ of damage and quite a bit of chaos, especially with so many defi projects on chain

author: .vbuterin
content: My own preference is for gas limit increases to wait for berlin, but there's other opinions (both more progressive and more conservative than me) too
